Sinus rhythm is defined by:
1. Heart rate 50–100 bpm
2. P-wave precedes every QRS complex
3. P-wave positive in lead II
4. Constant PR interval

Bradycardia (HR < 50 bpm):
- Sinus bradycardia
- Sinoatrial block
- Sinoatrial arrest/inhibition
- Second-degree AV block
- Third-degree AV block
- Sick sinus syndrome (if symptomatic)
- Escape rhythms may occur

Tachycardia (HR > 100 bpm)
Narrow QRS (<0.12 s):
- Sinus tachycardia
- Atrial fibrillation
- Atrial flutter
- Atrial tachycardia
- AVNRT (AV nodal re-entry)
- AVRT (WPW syndrome)
- Multifocal atrial tachycardia

Wide QRS (≥0.12 s):
- Ventricular tachycardia (most common)
- Supraventricular tachycardia with bundle branch block
- Pre-excitation (WPW)
- Paced rhythm

Normal P-wave:
- Positive in leads II, III, aVF
- Duration < 0.12 s
- Amplitude ≤ 2.5 mm
- May be biphasic in V1 (small terminal negative deflection <1 mm)

Abnormalities:
- P mitrale: wide, notched P-wave → left atrial enlargement
- P pulmonale: tall, peaked P-wave → right atrial enlargement
- Absent or inverted P-wave: junctional rhythm or retrograde conduction

PR interval normal: 0.12–0.22 s

PR abnormalities:
- PR > 0.22 s: 1st-degree AV block
- Progressively longer PR → dropped beat: Mobitz I (Wenckebach)
- Fixed PR, dropped beat: Mobitz II
- No relation between P and QRS: 3rd-degree (complete) AV block
- PR < 0.12 s: pre-excitation (WPW)

Normal:
- Duration < 0.12 s (typically 0.07–0.10 s)
- Normal voltage: R > 5 mm (limb), R > 10 mm (precordial)
- Normal axis: –30° to +90°

Abnormal durations:
- Wide QRS (≥0.12 s): bundle branch block (LBBB, RBBB), VT, hyperkalemia, drugs (TCA, Class I antiarrhythmics), pacing
- Low voltage: <5 mm limb, <10 mm chest leads — causes: COPD, effusion, obesity, hypothyroidism, pericarditis, amyloidosis
- High voltage: LVH, RVH, young athletic individuals
- LVH: S(V1 or V2) + R(V5 or V6) > 35 mm

Pathological Q waves: ≥0.03 s and/or ≥25% R amplitude in ≥2 contiguous leads → myocardial infarction

Axis deviation:
- Right axis deviation (> +90°): RVH, PE, COPD, LPFB, lateral MI
- Left axis deviation (< –30°): LAFB, LVH, inferior MI, LBBB
- Extreme axis deviation: VT, misplacement, dextrocardia

Normal: flat and isoelectric; measured at J point.

ST Elevation:
- Physiologic: early repolarization, male/female pattern (V2–V4, concave)
- Pathologic: STEMI, Prinzmetal angina, pericarditis, Brugada, LV aneurysm, Takotsubo, hyperkalemia, LVH, LBBB

ST Depression:
- Pathologic: ischemia, NSTEMI, reciprocal change, digoxin effect
- Physiologic/Other: LVH, RVH, tachycardia, hyperventilation, hypokalemia, BBB

Measurement criteria for STEMI:
- Men ≥40: ≥2 mm (V2–V3), ≥1 mm (other leads)
- Men <40: ≥2.5 mm (V2–V3), ≥1 mm (other leads)
- Women: ≥1.5 mm (V2–V3), ≥1 mm (other leads)

Normal:
- Concordant with QRS; positive in most leads (except aVR, sometimes III, V1)
- Highest amplitude in lead II and V2–V3

Abnormalities:
- Inversion: ischemia, post-ischemic (Wellens’), PE, CNS event, pericarditis, cardiomyopathy
- Tall (hyperacute): early STEMI, hyperkalemia, LVH, LBBB
- Flattened: ischemia, electrolyte imbalance
- Persistent juvenile pattern: inversion in V1–V3 in young adults
- Global inversion: rare, idiopathic or CNS-related

QTc (Bazett’s formula):
- Normal: ≤0.45 s (men), ≤0.46 s (women)
- Short: ≤0.32 s
- Long: >0.46 s (women), >0.45 s (men)

QT prolongation causes:
- Drugs: antiarrhythmics (amiodarone, sotalol), tricyclics, SSRIs, macrolides, quinolones, chloroquine, lithium
- Electrolyte disturbances: hypokalemia, hypocalcemia, hypomagnesemia
- Ischemia, cardiomyopathy, hypothyroidism, hypothermia
- Congenital LQTS (genetic variants)

QT shortening:
- Hypercalcemia, digoxin, hyperkalemia

U-wave:
- Seen best in V3–V4, amplitude ≤25% of T-wave
- Prominent: bradycardia, hypokalemia
- Inverted U: ischemia, LVH

Always compare with prior tracings.
New Q waves, ST/T changes, or QRS morphology changes often indicate acute or evolving pathology.
Interpret ECG findings only in clinical context — e.g., ST elevation without chest pain may be benign early repolarization.

ST elevation + reciprocal depression → STEMI
ST elevation + pericarditic concave shape + PR depression → Pericarditis
ST depression + T inversion (V4–V6) → NSTEMI / ischemia
Short PR + delta wave → WPW syndrome
Wide QRS + left axis deviation → LBBB
Wide QRS + right axis deviation → RBBB or RVH
QT prolongation + torsades → Drug or electrolyte induced
Bradycardia + QT prolongation → Risk of torsades
Tall P in II + right axis deviation → Right atrial hypertrophy
Broad P + left axis deviation → Left atrial enlargement
Dominant R in V1 + right axis deviation → RVH or posterior MI
Negative T + prolonged QT → Ischemia, CNS event
Low voltage + electrical alternans → Pericardial effusion
ST elevation V1–V3 with RBBB-like pattern → Brugada syndrome
Diffuse T inversion + QT prolongation → Myocarditis, Takotsubo
Sinus tachycardia + S1Q3T3 pattern → Pulmonary embolism

Normal axis: net positive QRS in I and II
Right axis deviation: negative QRS in I, positive in II
Left axis deviation: positive QRS in I, negative in II
Extreme axis: negative QRS in both I and II

LVH: S(V1) + R(V5 or V6) > 35 mm; left axis; ST depression (strain) in lateral leads
RVH: R(V1) > 7 mm, right axis deviation, dominant R in V1
LAE: P mitrale
RAE: P pulmonale

RBBB: QRS ≥0.12 s, rsR’ in V1, wide S in I, V6
LBBB: QRS ≥0.12 s, broad/notched R in I, V6, absent q in I, V6
LAFB: Left axis deviation, qR in aVL
LPFB: Right axis deviation, rS in I/aVL, qR in III/aVF
